constraints_details.constraints_layer_description: CONARA Name: Fairfield/Knights Park Conservation Area
AIRCZ Type:: Gatwick Airport Wind Turbine Consultation Zone:Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Gatwick Airport Limited, 7th Floor Destinations Place, London Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH06 0NP

AIRCZ Type:: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT

description: Erection of 1no. two storey (five-bedroom) single family dwellinghouse (following demolition of existing dwelling) with associated cycle storage and refuse storage facilities
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: As required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

A sample of the facing materials to be utilised in the development hereby permitted shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before any works on site are commenced. The development shall then be built in accordance with these approved samples.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase, and to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Detailed drawings at a scale of 1:20 of the following shall be submitted to and be approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before any works above damp proof course level. The development shall be carried out strictly in accordance with the approved details.(a) Front elevation windows(b) The traditional detailing around windows and front doorsReason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The levels of buildings within the site shall only be in accordance with details which shall have previously been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before development is commenced.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and to ensure that the appearance and functioning of the development is satisfactory and to safeguard the amenities of adjoining occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012

No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction logistic plan has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for work traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Means of enclosure of the site.(h) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(i) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

The development hereby approved shall not commence until a Sustainable Drainage Strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan of surface water drainage for the site using Suds methods has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved Sustainable Drainage Strategy prior to the first occupation of the dwelling and maintained thereafter for the lifetime of the development.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to prevent the increased risk of flooding by ensuring the provision of a satisfactory means of surface water disposal is incorporated into the design and the build of the proposed development, in accordance with Policies 5.2 and 5.3 of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

No work relating to the development hereby approved, including works of demolition or preparation prior to building operations, shall take place other than between the hours of 08:00 and 18:00 Monday to Friday and 08:00 to 13:00 Saturdays and at no time on Sundays or Bank or National Holidays.Reason: To protect the occupiers of neighbouring properties from noise and disturbance outside the permitted hours during the construction period, in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

Prior to the occupation of the approved development, a plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority indicating the positions, design, materials and type of all gates, boundary treatment, fences and means of enclosures to be erected. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved plan before the building is occupied.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interest of visual amenity, in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, any windows or rooflights in the side (west) elevation and situated at first floor level or above shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers, in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

Within 3 months of first occupation, evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4. Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide. Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day must be submitted to the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason: In order to ensure that all development is designed and built to make the most efficient use of resources, reduce its lifecycle impact on the environment and contributes to climate change mitigation and adaptation in accordance with Policy CS (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the approved development, details of the refuse and recycling provision on site shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved plan before the building is occupied.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, the proposed rear-most north facing first floor bedroom window, as shown on '10201 (Proposed First Floor Plan)' and '10402 Rev 02 (Proposed Rear and Side 2 Elevation)' shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, details of the means of enclosure for the site shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for approval in writing. The approved means of enclosure shall be implemented prior to beneficial occupation of the development and be permanently retained thereafter.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed by relevant consultants and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 52 (Car Parking) of planning permission 21/04022/FUL, which states:Condition 52 (Car Parking) - Prior to commencement of the car park, details shall be submitted to demonstrate howthe car park can be repurposed. The car park shall be implemented in accordance with the approved details.Reason: To reduce waste and improve sustainability in accordance with Policy SI 2 Minimising greenhouse gas emissions of the London Plan.

Consultations10no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. One representation received - neutral in content. Points raised duly noted by planning officer, however, the points raised do not materially affect the assessment of this application. Environmental Health Officer: No objection, subject to condition relating to noise rating level of the proposed air conditioning unit - as applied.ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for the erection of a single storey rear conservatory.Site and SurroundingsThe application site comprises of a two-storey, end terrace property. The surrounding properties comprise of a mix of terraced, semi-detached and detached two-storey dwellinghouses.The application site is not located within a Conservation Area and does not comprise of a statutory or locally listed building. Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Character and Appearance; -	The Impact upon Residential Amenity; and-	Fire SafetyCharacter and Appearance Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed single-storey rear extension would not be visible from the streetscene, contained behind the existing built form. The proposals involve the erection of a rear conservatory type structure measuring 3.3m in depth, and 4.4m in width. The extension is proposed to have a pitched roof to a maximum height of 3.2m (2.4m to eaves). The proposed extension is considered minor in its scale and appropriate in its design, in keeping with the rear elevation of the host building. Having regard to the above officers consider that there would be no material impact from the proposed development on the character and appearance of the area.Impact upon Residential AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed rear single-storey extension would cause no significant increase in the loss of privacy, loss of daylight, sense of enclosure or loss of outlook to the adjoining properties. Accordingly, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of residential amenity.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the relevant policies of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012).The proposal by virtue of its scale, design and materiality is considered to be subservient to the host dwelling and would not result in harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling or wider area. In addition, the proposals would not result in materially harmful impact to neighbouring amenity by way of overlooking, loss of light or sense of overbearing or enclosure. Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED.

Application SiteThis application relates to a ground floor commercial unit facing the River Thames forming part of Bishops Palace House.The site is located within the designated Kingston Old Town Conservation Area. The building that the advertisement is to be displayed on is not a statutory or locally listed building. The following constraints are also relevant:Area of Archaeological SignificanceArticle 4 AreaCPZKingston Town Centre Key Area of ChangeKey ViewsPrimary Shopping AreaPrimary Shopping FrontagesThames - Side Strategic Area of Special CharacterThames Policy AreaFlood Zone 2 (medium probability) and Flood Zone 3a (high probability).ProposalThe application seeks advertisement consent for the display of 1no. internally Illuminated fascia sign, 1no. internally Illuminated projecting (hanging) sign and signage on proposed awningCONSULTATIONS14no. surrounding owner/occupiers were notified of the application.  No responses were received.   Kingston Town Centre Conservation Area Advisory Committee: No objection.RBK Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer: No objectionsASSESSMENTThe main issue to assess in the consideration of this application is the impact that the development would have on the character of the area and the streetscene and impact upon heritage assets and impact upon highway safety.Character and AppearanceParagraph 136 of the NPPF states that the quality and character of places can suffer when advertisements are poorly sited and designed. A separate consent process within the planning system controls the display of advertisements, which should be operated in a way which is simple, efficient and effective. Advertisements should be subject to control only in the interests of amenity and public safety, taking account of cumulative impacts. Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The Council's Supplementary Planning Document titled, "Shopfronts and Shopsigns" (2005) provides guidance on new shopfronts and signage (including projecting and illuminated). The proposals include the installation of illuminated replacement fascia signage to the front elevation, an illuminated projecting sign and a projecting awning. The proposed fascia sign would comprise of white lettering fixed to a black aluminium fascia board with brass edging. The fascia and signage is appropriately scaled in comparison to the existing building and other fascias and signage along the riverside frontage. The projecting sign comprises of brass letting on a Perspex sign with neon bordering. It projects approx. 1m beyond the fascia and is broadly the same in size as the existing projecting sign.The proposed awning projects approximately 2.6m from the shopfront with a clear head height of 2.2m. Similarly scaled awnings are common along this part of the riverside frontage. The levels of illumination to the signage would not create any significant light pollution.Overall, the design and materials are considered to be visually unobtrusive and are considered to both respect and be in keeping with the host building and the surrounding streetscene, thereby complying with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012.Impact upon Heritage AssetsSections 16 and 66 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) state that in considering whether to grant planning permission for development which affects a listed building or its setting, the local planning authority shall have special regard to the desirability of preserving the building or its setting or any features of special architectural or historic interest which it possesses.Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.Given the existing context of shopfronts along this part of the riverside, the proposals are considered to be sympathetic to the scale, mass, height and aesthetic attributes of the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area and would not result in any harm to the heritage asset. Highway SafetyThe NPPF requires that in assessing applications for development, it is ensured that: appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport modes can be - or have been - taken up; safe and suitable access to the site can be achieved for all users; and any significant impacts from the development on the transport network (in terms of capacity and congestion), or on highway safety, can be cost effectively mitigated to an acceptable degree. Development should only be prevented or refused on highways grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or the residual cumulative impacts on the road network would be severe. Local Planning Authorities are expected to have regard to its effect upon the safe use and operation of any form of traffic or transport on land (including the safety of pedestrians), on or over water, or in the air. Public safety considerations, the second arm of control over advertisements, do not arise very frequently. However, when it can be shown that signs would be confused with traffic signals or the visibility of drivers is impaired, a solid and sustainable ground for refusal of Advertisement Regulation consent is provided. The signage would be illuminated but would not be visible from the highway. The signage and canopy would not conflict with or impede the free-flow of pedestrian or vehicular movement or create a distraction to highway users. It would therefore not result in a distraction to highway users and would not prejudice highway safety. The proposed signage is therefore in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy. Conclusion The proposed signage and awning are considered to both respect and be in keeping with the host building and the surrounding streetscene and would not result in harm to the character and appearance of the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area. The proposal therefore complies with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012.The proposals would not have any material effect on highway safety. The proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which otherwise indicate that advertisement consent should be refused. Therefore, it is recommended that advertisement consent be granted. Recommendation That advertisement consent should be GRANTED.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

The application site is located on the north side of Hook Rise North on the corner of the west side of Fullers Way North. The A3 is adjacent to the south of the site. The site is vacant with its former use being for storage of cars.The surrounding area is mixed in use and the site is not located in a conservation area and does not form part of the curtilage of a listed building.A new 3 - 4 storey building comprising 9 flats was approved on the site through 19/02048/FUL. Planning HistoryAny relevant planning history for the site has been taken into account in considering this application and recent planning history is available to view on the Council's website.AssessmentSection 96A gives Councils the power to make non-material changes to planning permission. The legislation states:(1) A local planning authority may make a change to any planning permission (granted following an application to the authority), relating to land in their area if they are satisfied that the change is not material.(2) In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission.(3) The power conferred by subsection (1) includes power to make a change to a planning permission,(a) to impose new conditions(b) to remove or alter existing conditions(4) The power conferred by subsection (1) may be exercised only on an application made by or on behalf of a person with an interest in the land to which the planning permission relates.The National Planning Practice Guidance notes that there is no statutory definition of "non-material" and it is dependent on the context of the overall scheme. Under government guidance the local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, what may be non-material in one context may be material in another. The definition of non-material is the responsibility of each local planning authority to determine. The judgement on "materiality" in any particular case is one of fact and degree, also taking into account the likely impacts of the amendment. Materiality is considered against the development as a whole, not just a part of it.Although what defines a non-material amendment is to the discretion of the local authority concerned and lacking in legal definition, the following key tests could be applied in assessing the acceptability of a change to an approved scheme under the non-material amendment procedure:  -Is the proposed change material/significant in terms of its scale (magnitude, degree etc) in relation to the original approval? - Would the proposed change result in a development that will appear noticeably different to what Official interested parties may have envisaged? - Are the changes of consequence? - Could the change result in an impact on the amenity of occupiers of adjoining properties? - Would the interests of any third party or body who participated in or where informed of the original decision be disadvantaged in any way? - Would the amendments be contrary to any planning policy of the Council?Officers Comment: The proposal is for a minor reduction to the depth of the approved building at the first floor level. The ground floor (parking) and second and third floors (which are set back) are unaffected. This is not considered to give rise to a significantly different appearance in the context of the overall scheme. The proposed change will move the building further away from the neighbouring X at the first floor level and so is not considered to impact on the amenity of occupiers of adjoining properties or result in the interests of any third party or body who participated in or were informed of the original decision being disadvantaged in any way.The proposal will result in a small reduction in the GIA of the associated first floor 1 bedroom unit and private balcony. However, this is only a minor reduction and the relevant standards set out in the Nationally Described Space Standards, London Plan and RBK Residential Design SPD are still satisfied.As such, the Council considers the amendment to the proposal to be non- material changes and, as such, it is recommended that a S96A application for a non-material amendment is granted.

Consultations6no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. No representations received within the timeframe given. Officers note that one objection has been submitted but is not valid given it was received outside of the representation deadline. Officer comment: Notwithstanding the above, the objection raises concerns relating to the scale of the proposed extension, loss of light and inaccuracies of the plans.ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for the erection of a single storey rear extension.Site and SurroundingsThe application site comprises of a two-storey, mid terraced property. The surrounding properties comprise of a mix of terraced, semi-detached and detached two-storey dwellinghouses.The application site is not located within a Conservation Area and does not comprise of a statutory or locally listed building. Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Character and Appearance; -	The Impact upon Residential Amenity; and-	Fire SafetyCharacter and Appearance Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed single-storey rear extension would not be visible from the streetscene, contained behind the existing built form. The proposals involve the erection of a rear extension partially measuring 4m and partially measuring 2m in depth, spanning the full width of the dwelling. The extension is proposed to have a flat roof with one flush rooflight. The proposed extension is considered minor in its scale and appropriate in its design, in keeping with the rear elevation of the host building. The proposed extension would broadly meet the criteria set out in the Residential Design Guide SPD for rear extensions in terms of its depth and would fully comply with the criteria with respect to the proposed height of the extension.Having regard to the above officers consider that there would be no material impact from the proposed development on the character and appearance of the area.Impact upon Residential AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.(It is noted that the plan is inaccurate in that the annotations incorrectly plot the neighbouring properties either side of the application dwelling. Officers note the true positions of No.s 85 and 89 in relation to the application dwellinghouse.)The proposed rear single-storey extension would project 2m from the rear building line of No. 85 and 1.1m from the rear building line of No. 89. The proposals are not considered to cause any significant increase in the loss of privacy, loss of daylight, sense of enclosure or loss of outlook to the adjoining properties. Accordingly, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of residential amenity.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the relevant policies of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012).The proposal by virtue of its scale, design and materiality is considered to be subservient to the host dwelling and would not result in harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling or wider area. In addition, the proposals would not result in materially harmful impact to neighbouring amenity by way of overlooking, loss of light or sense of overbearing or enclosure. Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed by relevant consultants and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 62 (Drinking Water Infrastructure) of planning permission 21/04022/FUL, which states:Condition 62 (Drinking Water Infrastructure) - Prior to above ground works, plans and details shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority demonstrating the provision and future management of free drinking water within the public realm. The plans and details shall show the location and design of the proposed drinking water infrastructure, along with measures to ensure its future maintenance and management. The development shall be carried out in accordance with these plans and details, and drinking water made available to the public for free in accordance with the plans and details prior to occupation of the development, and in perpetuity.Reason: To comply with Policy D8 (Public realm) of the London Plan 2021.

Application SiteThe site comprises an end terrace dwelling within the Tudor Estate Local Area of Special Character.ProposalErection of hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions with 2no. rooflights to front roofslope.Consultation5x neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; - The impact of the development on the Tudor Estate Local Area of Special Character; and,- The impact of the development on Fire Safety.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Hip to gable roof extensions are not strictly in accordance with guidance given ln the Residential Design SPD. However, overall the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design, particularly as a similar hip to gable loft conversion with rear dormer was considered permitted development with the granting of Certificate 14/12977/LDP at no.26.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. HeritageParagraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.The Tudor Estate Local Area of Special Character is a non-designated heritage asset.  Paragraph 203 of the NPPF states that:The effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining the application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement will be required having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Officer comment: As set out above, it is considered that there would be no adverse impact in terms of character and appearance as a result of the proposals.  Therefore, it follows that there would be no harm to the significance of the non-designated heritage asset. Overall, the proposed development is considered to preserve the character and appearance and significance of the Tudor Estate Local Area of Special Character.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy for 42 Wolsey Drive. However, Officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

Reasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans/documents submitted for the purposes of this application are consistent with the parent planning permission reference 20/02942/FUL, however, any inconsistencies would be resolved in favour of the parent permission. An Application for Approval of Details Reserved by Condition should not be used to evolve or modify the scheme in a way that is substantially different from that set out in the application.

Condition 20 (Construction and Environmental Management Plan) of planning permission 20/02942/FUL states:Prior to commencement of development in each Development Plot or Phase a Construction and Environmental Management Plan (CEMP) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The CEMP shall then be reviewed and updated prior to commencement of development in each Phase and an updated version submitted to the Local Planning Authority for approval prior to commencement of development in each Phase unless it is agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority that no amended version is warranted. The CEMP shall include specific details for: 1. the control of construction noise and vibration during hours of noisy activities; an updated Construction Logistics Plan (CLP) to include - a construction waste and material management, transportation and disposal strategy; including construction delivery booking and construction vehicle holding arrangements; site access and car parking arrangements; construction phasing and agreed routes; timings; travel plan for staff/personnel involved in construction.1. air quality measures for the control and monitoring of emissions (including from construction vehicles), dust, fine particles and odours; a Dust Management Plan (DMP). The DMP will need to detail the measures to reduce the impacts during the construction phase. 2. construction traffic routing through the area and the site and the development site, including details of signage and an enforcement system for breach of its provisions; 3. a low emission strategy for construction traffic and machinery; 4. piling or other penetrative methods of foundation design in relation to risks to underlying groundwater; 5. measures to protect controlled waters from construction processes and contamination; 6. measures to minimise cross contamination on site; 7. measures to deal with unexpected contamination on site; 8. measures for the protection of invertebrate species and enhancements for them, including provisions for dealing with any species that are discovered during the works, and a programme of timing for the works; 9. details of security of the construction site in relation to the boundary of the development site; 10. details of coordination with sites abutting the application boundary;11. hours of construction and details to minimise disturbance to residents;12. access through the site during works and upon completion of works in relation to any phasing, including the connections with any completed phases, and connections to the surrounding area and its network of cycle paths, roads and footpaths; and13. any temporary works, including any boundary treatment around later phases. 14. Provisions for pedestrians shall be fully accessible to all including people with disabilities. 15. details of cranes and other tall construction equipment (including the details of obstacle lighting) - Such schemes shall comply with Advice Note 4 'Cranes and Other Construction Issues'(available at firewww.aoa.org.uk/policy-campaigns/operations-safety).The development shall not be undertaken otherwise than in accordance with the CEMP approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing with the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure construction works and traffic impacts are minimised, to protect amenities of neighbouring occupiers and occupiers of the new residential units within the development itself and to minimise any harm to biodiversity interests of the area.Officer response: The Council's Environmental Health Officer and Highways Officer raised no objections to the information provided for Condition 20 (Construction and Environmental Management Plan) in relation to Plot B Phase 1. As such, condition 20 (Construction and Environmental Management Plan) in relation to Plot B Phase 1  is hereby approved.

Reasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans/documents submitted for the purposes of this application are consistent with the parent planning permission reference 20/02942/FUL, however, any inconsistencies would be resolved in favour of the parent permission. An Application for Approval of Details Reserved by Condition should not be used to evolve or modify the scheme in a way that is substantially different from that set out in the application
